message_1: A coffee shop has a mean daily revenue of $800 with a standard deviation of $50. If a random sample of 25 days is selected, what is the probability that the sample's mean daily revenue will be less than $790? (Assuming the Central Limit Theorem holds)
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the Central Limit Theorem and the z-score formula. The Central Limit Theorem states that the distribution of sample means will be approximately normally distributed with a mean equal to the population mean and a standard deviation equal to the population standard deviation divided by the square root of the sample size.

Given:
Population mean (μ) = $800
Population standard deviation (σ) = $50
Sample size (n) = 25
Sample mean (x̄) = $790

First, we need to find the standard deviation of the sample mean (σx̄). We can do this using the formula:

σx̄ = σ / √n

σx̄ = 50 / √25
σx̄ = 50 / 5
σx̄ = 10

Now, we will find the z-score for the sample mean. The z-score is the number of standard deviations away from the population mean a particular value is. We can find the z-score using the formula:

z = (x̄ - μ) / σx̄

z = (790 - 800) / 10
z = -10 / 10
z = -1

Now that we have the z-score, we can find the probability that the sample mean is less than $790 using a z-table or a calculator with a normal distribution function. The probability corresponds to the area under the standard normal curve to the left of the z-score.

P(x̄ < 790) = P(z < -1)
P(z < -1) ≈ 0.1587

So, the probability that the sample's mean daily revenue will be less than $790 is approximately 15.87%.
